text: Mr. Spicer: Good afternoon, everyone.
There&#39;s a lot going on today, so I&#39;m going to
keep this on the briefer side.
This morning, the President announced the
official approval of the presidential permit for
the Keystone XL pipeline.
The last administration spent eight years delaying
this enormous investment in American
energy independence.
President Trump is moving this project forward in
just eight weeks.
And just as he promised, it&#39;s an even better deal
for the American people than before he
took office.
This project will directly generate an estimated
16,100 jobs, according to the State Department --
all without spending a dime of taxpayer money.
In many ways, this project represented everything
that was wrong with the infrastructure permitting
of the United States.
TransCanada spent an incredible amount of
resources attempting to comply with government
regulations, only to be denied and delayed for
political reasons.
But the days of pointless government bureaucracy
holding up progress and production have ended.
By simply getting excessive, duplicative
regulations out of the way, we can make
infrastructure projects more attractive -- a more
attractive prospect for private investors, and
encourage even more projects like this one.
Immediately following the announcement by
TransCanada, the President announced that Charter
Communications has committed to investing $25
billion here in the United States and hiring an
additional 20,000 American workers over the
next four years.
Charter Communications is truly an example of how
American leadership can turn a downturn entity
into an amazing success.
Five years ago, Charter Communications was a
struggling company that had slowly emerged
from bankruptcy.
Today, thanks to hard work and great leadership of
Chairman and CEO Tom Rutledge, it is the
fastest-growing television, Internet,
and voice company in the nation.
And, most importantly, as Charter grew, American
jobs grew, as they brought back many jobs that had
previously been shipped overseas.
Today, Charter is also committed to completely
ending its offshore call centers, basing 100
percent of them in the United States.
Together, the TransCanada and Charter Communications
announcement demonstrate the new economic model of
what the President called The American Model.
By slashing job-killing regulations and reducing
government burdens and lowering taxes, we will
make it easier for all businesses to grow right
here at home, generating jobs and boosting our
economy by getting government out of the way.
Following these big announcements, the
President had lunch with Secretary of the
Treasury Steve Mnuchin.
He was joined by Speaker Paul Ryan -- I&#39;ll get to
in a second on that.
Later in the afternoon, the President will host a
Greek Independence Day celebration.
And as I mentioned yesterday, at 4 o&#39;clock he
will meet with about two dozen Medal of Honor
recipients to honor Medal of Honor Day, which is
technically tomorrow.
He&#39;s honored to be hosting these great men and women
of our Armed Services, the greatest force for peace
and justice the world has ever known.
And obviously, later today, the House will be
voting on the American Health Care Act.
The current vote is scheduled for 3:30 p.m.
The President has been working the phones and
having in-person meetings since the American Health
Care Act was introduced.
He&#39;s left everything on the field when it comes
to this bill.
The President and congressional Republicans
promised the American people that they would
repeal and replace this broken system.
Obamacare&#39;s Washington-driven,
one-size-fits-all plan had seven years to prove its
case, and look what it&#39;s left us with: Skyrocketing
premiums -- on average, premiums for Obamacare
benchmark plans increased 25 percent in 2017.
Unaffordable deductibles -- the two most popular
Obamacare health plans have average deductibles
equivalent to 10 percent and 6 percent of the
median American household income.
With these high deductibles, many people
have, technically, insurance, but nothing
that they can afford to use.
Fewer choices -- one in five Americans have only
one insurer offering
Obamacare through exchanges.
And, of course, higher taxes.
Key conservative groups like the Tea Party Express
and the American Conservative Union have
added themselves to a long list of organizations
expressing their support for the American Health
Care Act because they know it&#39;s our chance, after the
American people have spent years suffering, to
finally repeal and replace the nightmare
of Obamacare.
The President looks forward to seeing the
House Republicans join with these influential
voices and vote in favor of the
American Health Care Act.
The President, as I mentioned, had Speaker
Ryan come up here and visit with him to update
him on the bill.
They are continuing to
discuss the way forward on this.
The Speaker is updating him on his efforts.
As I mentioned to you, the President has been working
throughout the week on this, calling early --
starting early in the morning and working till
late at night, calling with members,
visiting members.
By our count, over 120 members have personally
had a visit, call, or meeting here at the White
House in the past few days.
This is an extraordinary feat.
The President and his team have committed everything
they can to making this thing happen.
And the Speaker is going to continue to update him
on the way forward.
Finally, a few administrative
notes here at the end.
Yesterday, senior-level United States and Israeli
delegations concluded four days of intensive talks
with a particular focus on concrete, near-term
measures to improve the overall climate in order
to advance the prospects of a genuine and lasting
peace between Israel and Palestine.
The United States delegation was led by
Jason Greenblatt, Special Representative for
International Negotiation, and included
representatives of the NSC and the
Department of State.
A principal focus of the discussion was specific
measures that could have a meaningful impact on the
economic environment in the West Bank and Gaza,
allowing the Palestinians to more fully realize
their economic potential.
The two delegations also discussed Israeli
settlement construction.
The fact that both governments dedicated such
senior delegations for so many days reflects the
close cooperation between these countries and the
importance that both assign to this vital task.
Last night, the President announced his intention to
nominate several key additional people to the
administration, including Althea Coat-zee to be
Deputy Administrator of the Small Business
Administration; William Francis Hagerty IV to be
ambassador to Japan; Robert Sumwalt III to be a
member of the National Transportation Safety Board.
And also this morning, of note, the United States
District Court for the Eastern District of
Virginia upheld the President&#39;s revised
executive order protecting the nation from foreign
people who seek to do us harm into
the United States.
We&#39;re pleased with this ruling, which found the
plaintiffs have no likelihood of success on
the merits of their claims.
As the court correctly notes in its opinion, the
President&#39;s order falls well within his legal
authority to protect the nation&#39;s security.
We&#39;re confident the President&#39;s fully lawful
and necessary action will ultimately be allowed to
move forward through the rest of the system
-- court system.
In terms of the schedule for this weekend, the
President will spend a working weekend here in
Washington, and we&#39;ll update you with further
details regarding his schedule.
With that, I&#39;ll get to your questions.
Steve.
The Press Sean, is it your understanding that you
don&#39;t have the votes to pass the
healthcare legislation?
Is that the message that Speaker Ryan delivered today?
And if so, what lessons do you draw
from this process?
Mr. Spicer: Well, I think the Speaker is currently
having a conversation with him to talk about where
that vote count stands.
He&#39;s working with the members of -- you know
the President made a sell.
They had the Tuesday Group here.
There were 17 members here; 16 walked
out as a &quot;yes.&quot;
I think we&#39;ve had a group of members that we&#39;ve
continued to have a conversation with and try
to make -- frankly, at this point, it&#39;s not a
question of negotiating anymore.
It&#39;s understanding the greater good
that&#39;s at hand.
The President understands this is it.
We had this opportunity to change the trajectory of
healthcare to help improve -- put a healthcare system
in place and to end the nightmare that Republicans
have campaigned on called Obamacare.
I noted yesterday it was the seventh-year
anniversary of Obamacare.
We have an opportunity to make sure that was the
last one, and the question is, do members realize
this opportunity.
There&#39;s no question in my mind at least that the
President and the team here have left
everything on the field.
He has called every member that had a question or
concern, tried to, to the extent possible, take into
consideration ideas that would strengthen the bill.
And it&#39;s now going to be up to the members of the
House to decide whether or not they want to follow
through on the promise to that.
But we&#39;re going to continue to work with the
Speaker and the leadership there to see
where the votes are.
We&#39;re getting closer and closer, but you
need to get to 216.
And they&#39;re starting four hours of debate.
I expect a vote somewhere
around 3:30-4 o&#39;clock hour.
We&#39;ll see where we go.
Hunter.
The Press Thank you, Sean.
We&#39;re hearing that Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell
wanted to do a clean repeal and then
replace over time.
In retrospect, would that have been
a better approach?
And in general, do you think Paul Ryan has
handled this well?
Mr. Spicer: I don&#39;t know that that&#39;s
entirely the case.
I know that this was a joint effort.
This is something that the House determined in terms
of the three-pronged approach that we had.
So I don&#39;t know that I necessarily agree with the
assessment of how that happened.
The Press And, in general, is the White House happy
with how Paul Ryan has handled this?
Mr. Spicer: I think the Speaker has done
everything he can.
He&#39;s worked really closely with the President.
I think at the end of the day -- I said this
yesterday -- you can&#39;t force people to vote.
But I think we&#39;ve given them every single reason
to fulfill every pledge that they&#39;ve made, and I
think this is the right thing to do.
Maggie.
I don&#39;t want you to live-Tweet this thing.
The Press Thank you, Sean.
What is the White House&#39;s view if this does not pass
and there aren&#39;t the votes?
What does this mean going forward for other pieces
of the President&#39;s agenda -- tax reform
being the big one?
Mr. Spicer: Look, I&#39;ve said it before, I don&#39;t
think you can tie any of these together.
That&#39;s just not -- I think there&#39;s a huge
appetite for tax reform.
And I&#39;m not trying to juxtapose anything to do
with today&#39;s vote or not.
I think it will be great to see it put forward.
The President has put a lot of time and effort
into this, and I think he&#39;s made a strong case as
to why this has to happen, and I think we&#39;ve
worked with the House.
If we don&#39;t get -- regardless of what happens
today -- and I still feel optimistic that the
Speaker and the President and the Vice President --
we&#39;ve got a team that&#39;s been up on the Hill most
of today -- they&#39;re going to continue to try to get
every vote they can.
But that doesn&#39;t mean -- whether it&#39;s immigration
or tax reform, there&#39;s still a huge
appetite out there.
The Press Just to be clear, I mean, if this
fails today, is the President done
with healthcare?
Mr. Spicer: So negative.
(Laughter.)
The Press: That&#39;s what we&#39;re hearing.
Mr. Spicer: That&#39;s what you&#39;re hearing?
Well, I haven&#39;t heard that yet, so why don&#39;t we
continue with a very positive,
optimistic Friday.
The sun is coming out.
(Laughter.)
I feel really good.
So we&#39;re going to continue to work as late as we can
to get the votes.
And as I said, the upside is that we continue to
pick up votes, people continue to say that they
want to -- the question is, can we get to 2016.
But make no mistake about it, the President made it
clear last night -- this is it.
You have an opportunity to do what you&#39;ve told the
American people, the commitment that we as a
party have made, but this is your chance to do
what we&#39;ve done.
We&#39;ve listened, we&#39;ve incorporated, we&#39;ve
updated in every way possible.
I don&#39;t think -- when you look at legislative
efforts, I think the President has given
it his all.
And I think it shocked a lot of people, frankly,
how very, very detail-oriented, how
personal it was for him -- calling members as
early as 6:00 a.m.
in the morning and going to 11 o&#39;clock at night the
last several nights, sitting down, meeting
after meeting with them, coming back and revising
it, having his team back and forth.
Everything is out there.
And I think each of these members needs to make the
decision, whether or not they believe that they&#39;ve
-- at some point, you can only do so much, is what I
would honestly tell you.
And I think everything that we could possibly do
to listen to members, to get their concerns in this
piece of legislation, to make it as strong as
possible for the American people has been done.
The Press: But is the President comfortable then
with Obamacare continuing?
And what does he say to his supporters?
Mr. Spicer: No, he&#39;s not.
I mean, of course, he&#39;s not.
The Press: I mean, they voted for him with the
promise that he would repeal this.
Mr. Spicer: I mean, I&#39;m not even sure where to
start with that.
No, he&#39;s not, which is why he&#39;s literally put as much
effort as he has into repealing this.
But he&#39;s made it clear that this is our moment,
this is our opportunity to do it, but it is now up to
members to make that decision whether or not
they want to be part of this effort to
repeal Obamacare.
And if they don&#39;t -- and I think for a lot of the --
you saw the President&#39;s tweet this morning -- I
think for a lot of these members who life is as
important as well, this is your opportunity.
But it&#39;s ultimately them that have to go down in
the floor and cast that vote.
And I think we&#39;ve been able to cast a bunch of
votes over the past couple years when you knew a
President wouldn&#39;t sign it.
You have a President that&#39;s going to sign the
bill if you pass it.
And now is that time.
Zeke.
The Press: Some months ago at the Republican National
Convention, the President said -- &quot;I alone can fix it.&quot;
Throughout the entire campaign, his message to
his voters, the American people, was, he&#39;s a
businessman, he knows how to get deals done, he
knows how to break the gridlock in Washington,
he&#39;s the &quot;closer&quot; is what you said
earlier this week.
If this vote does go down, what does this say
about the President?
Is the President humbled by this process?
And will he readjust -- how will he readjust the
administration going forward?
Mr. Spicer: Let&#39;s not -- like I said to Jill,
I&#39;m still optimistic.
I feel like we&#39;re continuing to work hard.
But at the end of the day, you can&#39;t force somebody
to do something.
I think there&#39;s nobody that objectively can look
at this effort and say the President didn&#39;t do every
single thing he possibly could, with his team, to
get every vote possible.
And I think that&#39;s why I still feel
good about this.
But we are where we are, and members have got to
make that decision for themselves.
This is the final hour to make that decision.
Blake.
The Press: Sean, is it under any consideration to
pull the bill at all between now and then?
Mr. Spicer: You guys are so negative.
The Press: Well, there&#39;s reports out there that --
Mr. Spicer: I understand.
But there are reports out there -- the Speaker and
the President are talking now.
The Leader and the Whip are doing their
vote counts.
The debate is ongoing.
We&#39;re going to continue -- we are proceeding with
vote as scheduled.
John.
The Press: Take me through some of the -- if you
don&#39;t mind -- the thinking yesterday when the bill
was pulled and then the President had made the
decision -- or his team, they went to the Hill
saying, there&#39;s going to be a vote today.
At what point did he make that calculation?
Why did he make that calculation?
Can you bring us through some of that thinking?
Mr. Spicer: Yeah, I mean, there&#39;s a
couple of things.
One is, I think we wanted to be as open as possible
with the vote.
Having it on the current trajectory last night, it
was going into the wee hours of the morning, and
I don&#39;t think that that -- for all that we&#39;ve talked
about, that wasn&#39;t the appropriate way to vote.
I think we decided to work with the House and ask
that they postpone and make sure that it was done
in the light of day.
But I think that he&#39;s had enough discussions.
And it is not about improving the
deal anymore.
I think he has taken into consideration every
member&#39;s thoughts and concerns, and relayed
those to the House.
And I think to the extent that this balance of
trying to get to 216, in this case, is such that
there are some people that come in with ideas and
say, if you do that to get your vote, I&#39;m going to
give up 26, or to get these three, I&#39;m going
give up 12.
And I think we have struck the right balance right
now and incorporated it, and it&#39;s the strongest
possible bill.
But he&#39;s going to continue to work as hard as he can
until the very end.
Charlie.
The Press: How important is a live vote to the White
House and to the President to see who&#39;s on the side
and who&#39;s not?
Mr. Spicer: We&#39;ve seen the whip counts.
Mr. Scalise has done a phenomenal job with Leader
McCarthy of -- we know where the
vote count stands.
So we don&#39;t need a live vote to tell us
where the votes are.
People have been pretty straightforward with where
they are and what their outstanding issues are.
The Press: The President and the Speaker are
meeting right now.
Do you know -- can you tell us anything about the
character of that meeting, or what exactly they&#39;re
looking at going forward?
Mr. Spicer: Well, they&#39;re discussing,
they&#39;re not looking.
They&#39;re sitting down and talking about where it
stands, some of the outstanding issues, and
whether they&#39;re onesies or twosies or fives -- what
are the concerned and outstanding issues of some
of the blocs and some of the individuals,
and having a discussion on that.
Anita.
The Press: If the bill doesn&#39;t pass --
Mr. Spicer: There&#39;s somebody that&#39;s going to
ask when it passes, and you can --
The Press: Okay, well,
do you want to have a briefing right after the vote?
Mr. Spicer: No.
The Press: Okay.
(Laughter.)
Mr. Spicer: All right, score one for you.
(Laughter.)
The Press: If the bill doesn&#39;t pass,
does the President still have confidence in
the Speaker?
Mr. Spicer: I think he answered that
question earlier today.
The Press: Well, does he think that he should step
down if it doesn&#39;t get a vote?
Mr. Spicer: He answered that question earlier,
and he said he did.
So, asked and answered.
The Press: And then, logistically today, after
the vote, whatever happens, how will we get a
response from you all?
Mr. Spicer: Electronically or verbally,
but one of the two.
Peter.
The Press: Thank you, Sean.
This is the President&#39;s first foray into, let&#39;s
say, the sausage-making process, so to speak.
Has he reflected at all on the experience?
I mean, how does he feel it differs from, for
example, negotiating a real estate deal,
a business deal?
Is it more complicated?
Is it trickier?
What&#39;s his feeling about this?
Mr. Spicer: I think we&#39;ll have plenty of time to
reflect on it after we do this, so I know that --
I&#39;ll just leave it at that for now.
Kristen.
The Press: Thanks.
Without prejudging the outcome of the vote --
Mr. Spicer: Thank you.
(Laughter.)
The Press: -- does the President in any
way regret pursuing healthcare first, given
how complicated it has been?
Mr. Spicer: No.
I think if you think about it legislatively, in order
to maximize -- and I know for most people it doesn&#39;t
make a ton of sense, but the savings that you
achieve through the first reconciliation of
healthcare, which we&#39;re doing through the 2017
budget process, which still continues, allows us
to utilize the savings in that process to maximize
additional tax reform measures that will start
in the FY2018 reconciliation process.
So while that sounds like a ton of inside-baseball
gobbledygook, the reality is, is that in order to
maximize tax reform both on the corporate side, to
make our businesses more competitive and to give
individuals, especially middle-class Americans,
more tax relief -- doing this in that way maximizes
the amount of savings that you can use for the second
reconciliation package, which would be tax reform.
Doing it the first way, you can do -- but again,
you&#39;re not going to achieve the full potential
that you could if you did it the way that
is happening now.
But that being said, I mean, it&#39;s not a question
of -- we all knew how big this was -- it&#39;s one-fifth
of the economy -- and what it took.
The issue is, is that I think the disparate
interests that are there, and some of the
process-explaining, if you will -- the understanding
-- the way that this is happening, and I think,
legislatively, it&#39;s complicated.
And for a lot of folks that just understand, why
can&#39;t you do it all in one fell swoop?
What&#39;s the Byrd Rule?
What&#39;s reconciliation?
Why do you have to do it in three phases?
I think, for a lot of people, that is a little
bit complicated to understand.
And it&#39;s not just a question of understanding.
I think one of the other things that the President
and the team have found is that there&#39;s a lot of
issues where people are wondering, well, if I vote
for this how can I guarantee that I get
something in phase two -- which is the
administrative pieces that Secretary Price
would institute.
And then third is -- well, you know, the legislative
things that will take 60 votes, they complete the
overall package -- you know, how do I have -- and
so there&#39;s a lot of -- the comprehensive nature of
this makes it very complicated.
And I think that&#39;s a lot different.
Normally, you have one bill that sails through,
and it deals with all of these things, and you
can roll it all in.
If someone has an amendment, you add it in.
In this process, we&#39;re having to have all these
one-off discussions about, you know, will the Senate
accept this if you put it in; if you put it in, will
they -- not only will they accept it, but will the
Byrd Rule take place and kick out the whole thing.
That complicates this
probably like nothing else.
The Press: Understood.
Just to put a fine point on it, though, was it his
initial ask to do healthcare first, or did
House Speaker Paul Ryan say, I think this is --
Mr. Spicer: I think was something that, during the
transition, we sat down and gamed out in
coordination with the House in terms of what
should go first and why.
But again, it&#39;s not a question of just what
should go first, it&#39;s a question of if you don&#39;t
do it first, do you lose some of the potential in
savings that you would achieve through the
second reconciliation.
The Press: Wouldn&#39;t it have been wiser to try to work
with the Freedom Caucus, for example, on something
like infrastructure reform to build up some goodwill
with that caucus, and then come back to something
more complicated?
Mr. Spicer: No, I think -- look, Kristen, we&#39;ve
talked about this since 2010.
Every Republican, with the exception of probably a
handful, has campaigned from dog catcher on up
that they would do everything they could to
repeal and replace Obamacare.
And I think to get in and say, hey, you should have
done something else wouldn&#39;t be fair to the
American people who have said, okay, I&#39;ll vote for
you but I want you to fulfill this pledge.
The Press: And just finally, does the buck
stop with him on this?
Mr. Spicer: Well, I mean -- like I said earlier,
you can&#39;t force someone to vote a certain way.
I think, in the sense that has he done every single
thing, has he pulled out every stop, has he called
every member, has he tweaked every tweak, has
he done every single thing he can possibly, and used
every minute of every day that&#39;s possible to get
this thing through, then the answer is yes.
Has the team put everything out there?
Have we left everything on the field?
Absolutely.
But at the end of the day, this isn&#39;t a dictatorship,
and we&#39;ve got to expect members to ultimately vote
to -- you know, how they will according
to what they think.
But I think they&#39;re -- as the President made clear,
they&#39;re the ones who have to go back and answer to
their constituents why they didn&#39;t fulfill a
pledge that they made.
The Press: Non-healthcare question for you.
Regarding these documents that Devin Nunes says show
incidental intelligence collection of identifying
information about people associated with the Trump
campaign, can you categorically rule out
that Chairman Nunes received or was alerted to
these documents from someone at the White House?
Mr. Spicer: I&#39;m not aware of where he got
the documents from.
I don&#39;t know.
The Press: Can you rule out that it came from
the White House?
Mr. Spicer: I can&#39;t -- I don&#39;t know where
he got them from.
He didn&#39;t state it.
So I don&#39;t have anything for you.
And so I cannot say anything more than
I don&#39;t know at this point.
Cecilia.
The Press: So if the President has done
everything he can possibly do, and the Speaker has
done everything he can possibly do, the team has
put everything on the table, who is to blame
right now for this hold-up, in your eyes?
Mr. Spicer: Well, again, let&#39;s wait and see how
this thing -- I&#39;m not assigning blame.
The Press: Well, but you wanted a vote even last
night or this morning, so there is a stall.
So from last night to this morning --
Mr. Spicer: No, no, no, we did want a vote last night,
and I think,
as I have mentioned, as we got into the evening
hours, the idea wasn&#39;t to bury this at
12:00 a.m. or 1:00 a.m. in the morning.
The Press: Initially, you were asking for one
yesterday, and there was a statement from your press
office that asked for one this morning.
Mr. Spicer: No, no -- and I&#39;m not backing away from that.
We wanted a vote yesterday.
But as the process went on, we realized that that
vote would occur in -- probably, actually, into
today, in terms of like calendar-wise, and that
doing it at 1:00 a.m., 2:00 a.m., 3:00 a.m.
in the morning was not something that would be in
keeping with what we had promised.
The Press: So who is to blame for the stall right now?
Is it the Freedom Caucus? Is it --
Mr. Spicer: I think it&#39;s not a blame.
Right now, it&#39;s a question of getting all these
members together and dealing with all -- I
mean, you&#39;ve seen the activity.
You&#39;ve seen the members go back and forth.
Right now, we&#39;re still in that active discussion
phase with trying to figure out who we can get
on board and whether or not we can move forward.
But this is -- we&#39;re not there yet.
The Press: But you put this ultimatum out there.
Is the President, right now, still confident that
he can see this bill through -- that you will
repeal and replace Obamacare?
Mr. Spicer: The President is confident that we have
done every single thing possible, made the case,
updated it, added and done everything to listen to
the concerns and to do everything that fulfills
the promises that we and members have made with
the American people.
John.
The Press: Thank you, Sean.
Without prejudging the outcome of the vote today,
but focusing on your comments and the
President&#39;s, saying this would be a vote against
life if people vote against it --
Mr. Spicer: Right.
The Press: -- several Republican members said
they did not want the vote on Planned Parenthood
in this particular bill.
Congressman John Faso of New York was
particularly outspoken.
Did anything come up in the negotiation or from
the White House saying they guarantee a separate
vote on Planned Parenthood and leave it
out of the bill?
Mr. Spicer: I&#39;m not aware of that, John.
I&#39;m not aware that that happened.
The Press: The White House -- from your tone and the
President&#39;s, the White House wanted the Planned
Parenthood vote in?
Mr. Spicer: I&#39;d have to go back and look at --

The Press: The other thing I wanted to ask was that

So if you vote no today, then what is your

The other choice is to do nothing, and that will
-- that is going to collapse the system.
Eamon.

Jen.

Mr. Spicer: I understand that, and so what -- I get it.

Jen.
The Press: Treasury Secretary Mnuchin was

Mr. Spicer: Again, I think tax reform is something
that we&#39;ve talked about.
There&#39;s plenty of time.
I think it&#39;s a goal, and I think it&#39;s an ambitious
one and I think it&#39;s one that we&#39;re going to
try to stick to.
But let&#39;s get by today, and then we&#39;ll lay it out.
But I think tax reform is something that the
President is very committed to.
You&#39;ve seen him very publicly in the last
couple of open events talk about how excited he is to
move on once this is done to tax reform.
Because he understands both sides of this -- that
the business piece of this -- we are so uncompetitive
when it comes to our other worldly competitors in
terms of our tax rate, and yet when we have these
discussions about keeping companies from either
shipping jobs overseas or growing -- bringing back

And I think he understands that on the tax front, we
can be a lot more competitive with the rest
of the world in growing American jobs here at home
and, frankly, expanding manufacturing if we lower
that, but also that the American middle class
desperately needs and wants a tax break, and I
think the more that we can do with that -- so this is
something that I think we&#39;re going to be
continuing to work on, and we&#39;ll have more on that later.
Trey.
The Press: Sean, how much credit will the President

Mr. Spicer: I&#39;m going to refer you to like the

Let&#39;s see where we go from here.

The Press: But he said we don&#39;t -- we won&#39;t know.

The Press: Thank you, Sean.
A couple questions.
First about Keystone.
What changed?
It seemed like it took forever in covering the
Obama administration for this thing to finally get
over the finish line.
It never did.
And relatively quickly -- less than 65 days in --
it&#39;s finally made its way over the finish line.
What changed, especially with respect to the State
Department&#39;s view of the Keystone XL pipeline?
And is it your opinion that it would be good to
hear from the President -- win, lose, or draw --

Mr. Spicer: So, simply put, on Keystone,
it was a priority.
I mean, the President came in, he signed an
executive order on it.
He had talked about it during the campaign and he
made it a priority.
He made it a priority for his team here at the White
House to get it done -- not only the jobs but
incorporating U.S.
steel and -- there was a lot of things.
But I don&#39;t think it&#39;s any simpler than he made it a
priority for him, his team, this administration,
the Department of State, and others -- and that&#39;s it.
He recognizes the importance of that to both
energy and to jobs and our economy,
and simply got it done.
And I&#39;ll leave it up to the President, once we go
forward, to see how it goes.
Margaret.
The Press: Sean, as a dealmaker, why does the
President feel that this take-it-or-leave-it

Mr. Spicer: Because I think he has done -- I

I&#39;ve taken your ideas.
At some point, we either have a deal or we don&#39;t.
And I think that&#39;s where the President finally drew

everything possible to address the concerns and

And I mean, I don&#39;t think you can

-- let&#39;s call the vote.

Mr. Spicer: I think that, at some point, there&#39;s a

Kaitlan.
